adrenal-mass.title: Incidental Adrenal Mass (>=1 cm)
adrenal-mass.subtitle: Detected on CT or MR
legend: If patient has clinical signs or symptoms of adrenal hyperfunction, consider biochemical evaluation.
Consider biochemical testing to exclude pheochromocytoma.
Benign imaging features = homogeneous, low density, smooth margins.
Suspicious imaging features = heterogeneous, necrosis, irregular margins.
APW = Absolute Percentage Washout; RPW = Relative Percentage Washout; HU = Hounsfield Unit; CS-MR = Chemical Shift MRI.

root.text: Incidental adrenal mass (>=1 cm) on CT/MR

children.text: HU <=10 or v signal on CS-MR = adenoma

children.outcome: Concerning for malignancy; consider biopsy or resection

children.text: No prior imaging, no history of cancer

children.outcome: Consider 12 month follow-up CT or MR

children.text: HU <=10 or v signal on CS-MR
HU >10 or no v signal on CS-MR

children.outcome: Cyst or hemorrhage; benign, no follow-up
Biopsy if appropriate or consider CS-MR if not done

children.text: No prior imaging, history of cancer
HU <=10 or v signal on CS-MR
HU >10 or no v signal on CS-MR

children.outcome: Cyst or hemorrhage; benign, no follow-up
Biopsy if appropriate or consider CS-MR if not done

adrenal-findings.title: Incidental Adrenal Mass (>=1 cm)
adrenal-findings.subtitle: Asymptomatic, detected on CT or MR
legend: Consider biochemical assays to determine functional status and exclude pheochromocytoma before biopsy/resection.
"No enhancement" applies only when both noncontrast and contrast imaging are available.
"Isolated" means no other metastatic disease identified.
Adrenal CT may use chemical-shift MRI (CS-MR).
APW = absolute percentage washout; RPW = relative percentage washout; HU = Hounsfield units; NCCT = noncontrast CT; F/U = follow-up; Hx = history; Ca++ = calcification.

root.text: Incidental, asymptomatic adrenal mass (>=1 cm) on CT/MR

children.text: <=10 HU or signal drop on CS-MR

children.outcome: Consider follow-up adrenal CT or resection

children.text: No prior imaging, no cancer history

children.outcome: Cyst or hemorrhage; benign, no follow-up
Imaging follow-up, biopsy, PET-CT, or resection depending on scenario

children.text: No prior imaging, cancer history, isolated adrenal mass

children.outcome: Cyst or hemorrhage; benign, no follow-up
Imaging follow-up, biopsy, PET-CT, or resection depending on scenario

thoracic-incidental-mediastinal-node.title: Incidental Mediastinal Lymph Node
thoracic-incidental-mediastinal-node.subtitle: Asymptomatic incidental mediastinal lymph node (Figure 1 from thoracic CT guidelines).
thoracic-incidental-mediastinal-node.image: downloaded_articles/downloaded_articles/Managing Incidental Findings on Thoracic CT Mediastinal and Cardiovascular Findings_files/gr1.jpg
legend: Short axis <15 mm or benign texture = no further work-up
Short axis >=15 mm with explainable disease = manage per disease
Short axis >=15 mm without explainable disease = consult/PET-CT/3-6 mo CT

children.text: Short axis < 15 mm or benign texture features
Clinical consultation and/or PET/CT and/or 3-6 month follow-up chest CT
On follow-up: Stable or decreased size

legend: Anterior/middle compartment: cystic vs not cystic
Posterior compartment: MRI

thoracic-incidental-pericardial.title: Incidental Pericardial Abnormality
thoracic-incidental-pericardial.subtitle: Asymptomatic pericardial abnormality (Figure 3 from thoracic CT guidelines).
thoracic-incidental-pericardial.image: downloaded_articles/downloaded_articles/Managing Incidental Findings on Thoracic CT Mediastinal and Cardiovascular Findings_files/gr3.jpg
legend: Cyst, HU <=10: no further work-up
Cyst HU >10 or thickened pericardium or fluid >50 ml or calcification

children.text: Cyst HU > 10 or thickened pericardium or fluid > 50 ml or calcification

children.outcome: Consider MRI or short-term CT follow-up

Figure 2: Cardiovascular findings

liver-mass.title: Incidental Liver Mass
liver-mass.subtitle: Detected on CT
legend: Low risk: age <40, no known malignancy, no hepatic dysfunction/risk factors, no symptoms.
Average risk: age >=40 with no known malignancy, hepatic dysfunction, abnormal liver function tests, or hepatic risk factors.

High risk: known primary malignancy with propensity to metastasize to liver, cirrhosis, or hepatic risk factors (hepatitis, NASH, alcoholism, sclerosing cholangitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, hemochromatosis, anabolic steroid use).
Follow-up: CT or MRI in 6 months; may need longer follow-up in high-risk patients.
Benign imaging features: sharp margins, homogeneous low density (~20 HU) or classic hemangioma/FNH/imaging features of perfusional changes.
Flash filling: uniform enhancement <1.5 cm equals hemangioma in low-risk patients.
Suspicious imaging features: ill-defined margins, heterogeneous, enhancement >20 HU, washout appearance, peripheral or early arterial enhancement, or portal venous hypoenhancement.
Diagnostic benign features for FNH/adenoma: arterial enhancement with central scar, persistent enhancement.
Follow-up for high-risk: evaluate or biopsy; core preferred.
No benign diagnostic imaging features: evaluate or biopsy as appropriate.

children.outcome: Benign; evaluate if possible FNH, adenoma
Follow-up, evaluate, or biopsy; core preferred

liver-findings.title: Incidental Liver Lesions (>=1 cm)
liver-findings.subtitle: Detected on CT
liver-findings.image: Management of Incidental Liver Lesions on CT_files/gr1.jpg
legend: If imaging is inadequate to determine benign vs suspicious features in a >=1 cm lesion, prompt MRI is advised.
Low-risk patient: no known primary malignancy, hepatic dysfunction, or hepatic risk factors.
High-risk patient: known primary malignancy with propensity to metastasize to the liver, cirrhosis, and/or other hepatic risk factors.
Follow-up MRI in 3-6 months. CT is acceptable for patients due for routine CT surveillance.

Benign features: sharp margin, homogeneous low attenuation (<=20 HU) on noncontrast and/or portal venous phase, or characteristic hemangioma, FNH, focal fatty sparing/deposition, or perfusional changes. Pseudoenhancement may elevate cyst HU.

Suspicious features: ill-defined margins, heterogeneous density, mural thickening or nodularity, thick septa, or portal venous attenuation >20 HU (without pseudoenhancement). Enhancement >20 HU on pre/post CT is suspicious; prefer MRI.

"Flash-filling" feature: uniform hyperenhancement relative to liver on arterial or late arterial/early portal venous phase. If additional phases show benign or suspicious features, categorize accordingly.

Lesions >1.5 cm without benign features should at least undergo prompt MRI; direct biopsy may be appropriate. MRI with gadoxetate is advised for suspected FNH vs adenoma, especially >3 cm and subcapsular.
If biopsy is pursued, core biopsy is preferred over fine-needle aspiration.

root.text: Incidental liver mass detected on CT

pancreatic-cystic.title: Asymptomatic Incidental Pancreatic Cystic Mass
pancreatic-cystic.subtitle: Detected on CT, MRI (with or without contrast) or US
pancreatic-cystic.image: incidental asymptomatic patient with pancreatic leasion.jpg
legend: Signs/symptoms: hyperamylasemia, recent onset diabetes, severe epigastric pain, weight loss, steatorrhea, jaundice.
Consider decreasing interval if younger, with limited life expectancy. Recommend T1-weighted MRI for routine follow-ups.
Recommend pancreas-dedicated MRI with MRCP.
If no growth after 2 years, follow-up yearly; if growth or suspicious features develop, consider resection.
BD-IPMN = branch duct intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm.

children.text: Uncharacterized cystic mass or other cystic neoplasm

children.outcome: Resect depending on comorbidities and risk

renal-noncontrast.title: Incidental Renal Mass on Noncontrast CT
renal-noncontrast.subtitle: Only unenhanced CT is available; does not contain fat.
renal-noncontrast.image: Management of the Incidental Renal Masson CT_files/gr1.jpg
legend: TSTC = too small to characterize.
If fat attenuation (< -10 HU), use the fat-containing renal mass pathway.

root.text: Incidental renal mass on noncontrast CT (no fat)

children.text: Likely benign cyst (visually much lower or higher than parenchyma)

children.outcome: MRI or CT without and with IV contrast within 6-12 months (prefer MRI)

children.text: Homogeneous mass without mural nodule, septa, or calcification

children.outcome: Benign simple cyst; no further work-up
Hyperdense Bosniak II cyst; no further work-up
MRI or CT without and with IV contrast to characterize (cystic vs solid)

children.text: Heterogeneous mass (wall thickening, septa, mural nodule, or calcification)
children.outcome: MRI or CT without and with IV contrast to characterize (cystic vs solid)

renal-contrast.subtitle: Only contrast-enhanced CT is available; does not contain fat.
renal-contrast.image: Management of the Incidental Renal Masson CT_files/gr2.jpg
renal-contrast.figureNote: Figure 2 is shown in the upper half of the source image (Figure 3 appears below).
legend: TSTC = too small to characterize.
If fat attenuation (< -10 HU), use the fat-containing renal mass pathway.

root.text: Incidental renal mass on contrast-enhanced CT (no fat)

children.text: Likely benign cyst (visually much lower than enhanced parenchyma)

children.outcome: MRI or CT without and with IV contrast within 6-12 months (prefer MRI)

children.text: Homogeneous mass without mural nodule, septa, or calcification

children.outcome: Benign simple cyst; no further work-up
MRI or CT without and with IV contrast to assess enhancement and characterize

children.text: Heterogeneous mass (wall thickening, septa, mural nodule, or calcification)
children.outcome: MRI or CT without and with IV contrast to characterize

renal-cystic-acr.title: Incidental Cystic Renal Mass (CT/MRI with and without IV contrast)
renal-cystic-acr.subtitle: Completely characterized cystic mass; does not contain fat.
renal-cystic-acr.image: Management of the Incidental Renal Masson CT_files/gr3.jpg
renal-cystic-acr.figureNote: Figure 3 is shown in the lower half of the source image (Figure 2 appears above).
legend: Use the Bosniak classification for cystic renal masses.
Morphologic change includes septa, wall thickening, or new nodularity.
Growth without morphologic change is not suspicious for malignancy.

children.text: CT or MRI at 6 and 12 months, then yearly for 5 years

renal-solid-acr.title: Incidental Solid Renal Mass or TSTC (CT/MRI with and without IV contrast)
renal-solid-acr.subtitle: Solid mass characterized on CT/MRI; does not contain fat.
renal-solid-acr.image: Management of the Incidental Renal Masson CT_files/gr4.jpg
legend: TSTC = too small to characterize.
Small renal neoplasm includes RCC, oncocytoma, and AML with minimal fat.

root.text: Incidental solid renal mass or TSTC

children.outcome: MRI or CT without and with IV contrast within 6-12 months

children.text: Follow-up MRI or CT at 6-12 months, then yearly for 5 years

children.outcome: Unlikely clinical significance; no further work-up

renal-fat.title: Incidental Renal Mass with Fat Attenuation
renal-fat.subtitle: Region of interest less than -10 HU.
renal-fat.image: Management of the Incidental Renal Masson CT_files/gr5.jpg
legend: Angiomyolipoma is most likely when fat is present without calcification.
Fat with calcification warrants CT or MRI without and with IV contrast.
Size >= 4 cm or symptoms prompt referral for management.

children.text: Multiple or growth based on prior studies
CT or MRI without and with IV contrast

renal-cystic.title: Incidental Cystic Renal Mass
renal-cystic.subtitle: Detected on CT
renal-cystic.image: incidental renal cystic mass on ct.jpg
legend: Follow only if non-neoplastic causes have been excluded; recommendations are general guidance.
Simple cyst (<1 cm) likely benign; further work-up often not useful.
Intervals may vary; longer intervals for masses staying unchanged.
In selected patients (e.g., young), early surgical intervention may be considered; minimally invasive options possible.
Morphologic change = change in feature characteristics such as number of septa, nodularity.
Bosniak III/IV masses are malignant in ~50% or more; management depends on life expectancy and comorbidities.
Limited life expectancy and comorbidities increase treatment risk.
Cystic masses <=1.5 cm or that cannot be characterized may not need further evaluation in poor life expectancy.
Percutaneous biopsy of Bosniak III masses may be considered though may not be diagnostic.

children.text: CT or MRI at 6 and 12 months, then yearly for 5 years
If follow-up appropriate, CT or MRI at 6 and 12 months, then yearly for 5 years

children.outcome: Surgery, follow-up, or no further follow-up based on life expectancy/comorbidities

children.text: If follow-up appropriate, CT or MRI at 6 and 12 months, then yearly for 5 years

children.outcome: Based on morphologic change, life expectancy, comorbidities

renal-solid.title: Incidental Solid Renal Mass
renal-solid.subtitle: Detected on CT
renal-solid.image: incidental solid renal mass on ct.jpg
legend: Follow only if non-neoplastic causes (e.g., infections, angiomyolipomas) have been excluded.
Differential diagnosis includes RCC, oncocytoma, angiomyolipoma; benign entities more likely in small masses.
Limited life expectancy/co-morbidities increase treatment risk; observation interval may vary.
Probable RCC if no detectable fat on CT/MRI using renal mass protocols.
If hyperattenuating and homogeneously enhancing, consider MRI and percutaneous biopsy to diagnose angiomyolipoma with minimal fat.
Surgical options include open or laparoscopic nephrectomy/partial nephrectomy; both provide definitive management.
Observation may be considered for small solid masses in limited life expectancy; thin (<=3 cm) small mass biopsy helps confirm diagnosis.
Probable RCC diagnoses also include oncocytoma and AML with minimal fat; biopsy can guide management.
Percutaneous biopsy can be utilized preoperatively to confirm RCC.

children.outcome: Follow-up until 1 cm: CT or MRI at 3-6 months and 12 months, then yearly
Follow-up until 1.5 cm: CT or MRI at 3-6 months and 12 months, then yearly

thyroid-pet.title: Incidental Thyroid Nodule
thyroid-pet.subtitle: Detected on 18FDG-PET or other nuclear medicine scans

children.text: ITN on PET/CT or PET/MRI without metabolic activity
children.outcome: Refer to recommendations for incidental thyroid nodule on CT/MRI

children.text: No suspicious CT or MRI findings

adnexal-cystic.title: Incidental Adnexal Cystic Mass (>=1 cm)
adnexal-cystic.subtitle: Post-menarchal, non-pregnant
adnexal-cystic.image: Management of Incidental Adnexal Findings on CT and MRI_files/gr1.jpg
legend: Exclusions: normal findings (corpus luteum), asymmetric ovary with normal shape, unimportant findings, prior characterization, or documented stability for >2 years.
Benign-appearing cyst must be unilocular, with benign features and <10 cm in maximum diameter; exceptions allowed for specific observations.
Probably benign cyst meets benign criteria except for specific observations (e.g., angulated internal walls, irregular shape, partial imaging, poor signal-to-noise).
Features of masses in this category include solid component, mural nodule, or higher than fluid attenuation/signal; layering hemorrhage if postmenopausal.
Ultrasound should be performed promptly if further evaluation needed.
Benign-appearing cyst <=5 cm with suspected layered hemorrhage in patient aged <=55 or within 5 years of menopause should be followed in 6-12 weeks.
Thresholds may decrease (e.g., 3 cm -> 1 cm) to increase sensitivity for neoplasm.
